Departamento de Ingeniería Química y Bioprocesos, Escuela de Ingeniería, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile Avenida Vicuña Mackenna 4860, Macul Santiago 7820436 Chile The effect of different supports (SiO₂, Al₂O₃, TiO₂, and ZrO₂) on nickel phosphide as an active phase in the reductive amination reaction (using aniline and octylamine) for the synthesis of 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidone was studied. The experiments were conducted at 200°C and 50 bar H₂, using dioxane as the reactive solvent. Various techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts, including N₂ adsorption–desorption, H₂-temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), pyridine-FTIR, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Firstly, the supports influenced the nickel species present on the surface and the number of acidic sites in each catalyst. Secondly, in the reaction between levulinic acid and aniline, the turnover frequency ( TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina ) for 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone production followed the order: NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. Regarding the reaction between levulinic acid and 1-octylamine, the TO F L 1 → 5 M P octylamine for 5-methyl-N-octyl-2-pyrrolidone production followed the order: NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. Finally, the supports influenced the type of nickel phosphide species present on the catalyst surface and, consequently, the hydrogenation rate to pyrrolidone molecules. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrogenation Nickel phosphide Reductive amination Support effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Levulinic acid (LA) is produced through the acid-catalyzed dehydration of hexoses, primarily derived from cellulose. It has been recognized as a key chemical platform for the production of various value-added compounds in the chemical industry, such as γ-valerolactone [1–3], α-angelica lactone [4,5], succinic acid [6,7], 2-methyl tetrahydrofuran [8,9], 1,4-pentanediol [10,11], N-alkyl-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidinones [12–15] and so on. Currently, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) is one of the most environmentally hazardous solvents that needs to be replaced. NMP is synthesized via the catalytic reductive amination of γ-butyrolactone and methylamine, both of which are derived directly from fossil resources, using H₂ as the reducing agent [16–18]. Alternatively, 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones can be synthesized through the same reductive amination reaction but directly from LA and a primary amine. Moreover, 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones have been proposed as direct substitutes for NMP, as they have not yet been classified as toxic under the European Union's Registration, Evaluation, Authorization, and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) regulation [19]. Therefore, 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones represent a viable replacement for NMP and can be used as solvents, intermediates in pharmaceutical synthesis, surfactants, and for other applications. In this context, catalytic reductive amination has been extensively studied as the primary reaction that converts carbonyl compounds and amines into imine groups, which are subsequently hydrogenated to obtain the desired amine product. Reductive amination can be performed using LA and primary amines to synthesize 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones with heterogeneous catalysts. A substantial body of literature exists on the use of noble metals for this reaction, including Pt [15,20–22], Au [23], Pd [23,24], Ru [25–27] and Ir [28]. Touchy et al. [15] conducted catalyst screening with a range of supported binary metal catalysts and supported Pt catalysts, evaluating the effects of the metal and support on yield. In their study, they maintained the same metal and metal oxide content across different supports—5 % metal and 7 % metal oxide. The best-performing catalyst was Pt-MoOx/TiO₂, achieving a 99 % yield, followed by Pt-MoOx/ZrO₂ (60 %) > Pt-MoOx/SiO₂ (52 %) > Pt-MoOx/Al₂O₃ (34 %); Pt/Al₂O₃ (89 %) > Pt/SiO₂ (77 %) > Pt/ZrO₂ (62 %) > Pt/TiO₂ (51 %); and Pt-VOx/TiO₂ (74 %) > Pt-WOx/TiO₂ (69 %) > Pt-ReOx/TiO₂ (58 %) > Pt-CrOx/TiO₂ (42 %). These results highlight the influence of supports on Pt-metal oxide catalysts, Pt catalysts, and different metal oxides supported on TiO₂ It is evident that the yields obtained with binary metal catalysts differed from those with monometallic Pt catalysts, with the most notable effect being the synergy between Pt and MoOx when supported on TiO₂. However, the influence of the support remains unclear, as the authors used the same metal content without considering variations in the specific surface area of the supports or metal dispersion, which would be necessary for a systematic study of support effects in the reductive amination reaction. Zhang et al. [24] investigated reductive amination using a Pd-based catalyst on different supports to evaluate their impact on the reaction. The highest yield was achieved with Pd/ZrO₂ (99 %), followed by Pd/Al₂O₃ (∼66 %) > Pd/TiO₂ (∼22.5 %) > Pd/SiO₂ (∼4.5 %). All catalysts had similar metal dispersion (21.5–30.1 %) and a Pd loading of ∼2.1 %. The authors demonstrated not only the effect of the support on reductive amination of LA but also the role of Lewis acid-base interactions between the catalysts and CO groups in promoting or hindering the formation of γ-valerolactone as a by-product. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and infrared (IR) spectroscopy of acetone revealed that Pd/ZrO₂ exhibited significantly stronger acid-base interactions with CO groups than the other catalysts. The study suggested that an increase in Lewis acid-base interactions enhances the electrophilicity of CO groups, favouring the formation of amine intermediates rather than direct hydrogenation of carbonyl groups. This finding highlights the crucial role of the support in modulating CO interactions during the reductive amination of LA. Although noble metal-based catalysts exhibit high yields for the production of 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones, it is well known that precious metals are scarce and expensive. This has driven the search for more abundant transition metals as alternatives for catalyzing the production of 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones. Nickel has been widely used in various hydrogenation reactions; however, there is limited research on its application in the reductive amination of LA. One such study was conducted by Gao et al. [29], in which the authors reported the synthesis of nickel supported on carbon nanotubes via the atomic layer deposition method, with an additional porous carbon coating. The proposed catalyst achieved a 99 % yield of 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones and demonstrated remarkable stability, maintaining its performance for up to 20 reaction cycles without sintering or leaching. Additionally, Amarasekara et al. [30] investigated Ni-Raney as a cost-effective catalyst for the reductive amination of LA, using ammonium formate as both the hydrogen and nitrogen source. Under the specified reaction conditions, the production of 5-methyl-2-pyrrolidones from LA reached a 94 % yield. A key advantage of this approach is that it employs a non-noble metal catalyst and does not require an external hydrogen source, as ammonium formate can dissociate into hydrogen and ammonium. Other nickel-based catalysts include nickel phosphides, which have been extensively used in hydrogenation reactions such as hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), hydrodesulfurization (HDS), and the conversion of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone. Nickel phosphides exhibit a higher density of Lewis acidic sites compared to nickel due to the electron-withdrawing effect of phosphorus on nickel. These catalysts exist in multiple phases, but the most studied is the Ni₂P structure, as it is one of the most stable. Several studies have investigated the effect of Ni₂P on different supports in hydrogenation reactions, including the conversion of tetralin to decalin [31], HDO of phenol [32], cresol [33], and guaiacol [34–36], as well as the HDS of dibenzothiophene [37] or thiophene [38]. Regarding the reductive amination of levulinic acid, Wang et al. [14] investigated the synthesis 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones from ethyl levulinate using only Ni2P/SiO2 in a flow reactor. Their study examined the effects of solvent nature, temperature, pressure, and other reaction parameters. Briefly, hexylamine was used as the nitrogen source, achieving a selectivity of 94 % towards 5-methyl-N-hexyl-2-pyrrolidone (HMP) with a 96 % conversion of ethyl levulinate at 170°C and 20 bar. Additionally, the authors proposed two reaction pathways for the formation of 5-methyl-N-hexyl-2-pyrrolidone. In the first pathway, ethyl 4-(hexylimino)pentanoate (EHP) undergoes hydrogenation to form ethyl 4-(hexylamino)pentanoate, followed by cyclization to HMP. In the second pathway, an equilibrium between imine and enamine species occurs, followed by ethanol elimination, ultimately leading to HMP formation. In a separate study, Wang et al. [39] evaluated the effect of Al₂O₃ as a support for Ni₂P in reductive amination using a continuous-flow reactor. The authors found that although Ni₂P/Al₂O₃ did not exhibit significantly lower hydrogenation activity, the HMP yield was reduced due to the occurrence of side reactions. Despite the works presented by Wang et al. [39], no research has compared the performance of SiO₂, ZrO₂, TiO₂, and Al₂O₃ as supports for nickel phosphide in this type of reaction using a batch reactor. Such a comparison is essential to obtain kinetic curves and evaluate the influence of different supports on nickel phosphide particles. Therefore, this work presents a systematic study to identify the effect of nickel phosphide on different supports for the production of 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones from levulinic acid (LA). The objective is to understand how the interaction between nickel phosphide and the support influence the reductive amination of LA in a batch reactor. To achieve this, four different supports—SiO₂, Al₂O₃, ZrO₂, and TiO₂—were selected and impregnated using the incipient wetness impregnation method, maintaining a constant atomic density across the supports. The catalytic performance was evaluated based on conversion and yield in two reactions: (i) between LA and aniline to produce 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone and (ii) between LA and octylamine to produce 5-methyl-1-octyl-2-pyrrolidone. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Chemicals Ni(NO3)2 ∙ 6 H2O, (NH4)2HPO4, distilled H2O, HNO3, SiO2 (silica grase), Al2O3, ZrO2 and TiO2. Levulinic acid, aniline, octylamine, γ-valerolactone, dioxane, n-dodecane, H2. Prior to use the supports for catalyst preparation, SiO2 and Al2O3 granules were crushed and sieved using a sieve of < 150 µm, and then dried at 110°C for 2 h. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All catalysts were prepared using the same procedure, taking the preparation of NiP/SiO₂ as an example. For the other supports, it is important to consider the differences in specific surface area when calculating atomic density to ensure that the same number of atoms per square nanometer is maintained. First, an aqueous solution of Ni(NO₃)₂∙6H₂O and (NH₄)₂HPO₄ was prepared, maintaining a P/Ni molar ratio of 2:1. The mixture of both salts in water resulted in a yellow-green precipitate. HNO₃ was then added dropwise until the precipitate completely dissolved, yielding a green solution. Subsequently, all catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method with the previously prepared aqueous solution. The impregnated support was allowed to mature at room temperature for 8 hours, followed by overnight drying. The catalysts were then calcined at a heating rate of 5°C min⁻¹ up to 550°C and maintained at this temperature for 4 hours to obtain oxide precursors. Before reducing the precursors, an N₂ gas flow was applied to create an inert atmosphere inside the quartz reactor. Then, an H₂ gas flow was used to reduce the oxide precursors at a flow rate of 100 mL min⁻¹ g⁻¹ and a temperature of 650°C for 2 hours, with a heating rate of 1°C min⁻¹ . All catalysts were prepared using the same procedure, and five catalysts were synthesized: NiP/SiO₂, NiP/Al₂O₃, NiP/ZrO₂, and NiP/TiO₂. All of them were designed to have the same theoretical atomic density of 3.73 atoms/nm² to ensure a fair comparison under the same nominal dispersion. The reactivation of catalyst was carried out at 650°C for 2 h with a heating rate of 10°C min−1 under a flow rate of 100 mL min⁻¹ g⁻¹ of hydrogen. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Textural characteristics were determined from N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196°C using a 3Flex Micromeritics analyzer. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, following the Rouquerol criteria. The total pore volume was obtained from the adsorbed N₂ volume at P/P₀ = 0.98. Finally, the average mesopore size distribution was evaluated using the BJH method. Temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR) experiments were performed on the same 3Flex Micromeritics instrument. The samples were heated at a rate of 10°C min⁻¹ up to 900°C under a 5.2 vol% H₂/Ar gas flow of 100 mL min⁻¹ . H₂ consumption was detected using both TCD and MS detectors. The chemical composition of nickel and phosphorus was determined using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). Prior to analysis, the samples were digested with concentrated nitric acid and hydrofluoric acid. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Polycrystal X’Pert Pro PANalytical instrument (UK) with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) and a graphite monochromator. For each sample, Bragg angles between 20° and 80° were scanned with a step size of 0.04° and a scanning rate of five steps per second. The crystallite size was calculated using the Scherrer equation. The morphology of the NiP catalyst particles was analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with a JEOL JEM 1200 EX II microscope. Several images of the samples were taken at a scale of 50–100 nm. A histogram analysis of the micrographs was performed using ImageJ software, based on over 200 particles per catalyst. The average particle diameter (dp) was calculated using the following equation: (1) d p = ∑ i n d i n where d i is the individual particle size, and n is the number of measured particles. Surface acidity measurements were performed using Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine. The spectra were recorded with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS10 spectrometer equipped with a heatable-evacuable reaction cell with CaF₂ windows, connected to gas-dosing and evacuation systems. Powdered samples (50 mg) were pressed into self-supporting wafers with a diameter of 20 mm. The samples were pretreated with hydrogen at 400°C for 1 hour and then cooled to room temperature. Pyridine was introduced at room temperature until saturation. The adsorption spectra (2 cm⁻¹ resolution, 100 scans) were recorded at room temperature after gas-phase removal by evacuation, and at different temperatures during heating under a helium flow. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using an Escalab 200 R spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA) equipped with a hemispherical analyzer and a non-monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). Calibration was carried out relative to the supports to enable comparison between oxidized and reduced catalysts. Specifically, SiO₂ (103.5 eV), TiO₂ (458.7 eV), ZrO₂ (182.8 eV), and Al₂O₃ (74.1 eV) were used as reference materials, with an instrumental error of less than 0.01 eV in energy determinations. The spectra of P 2p, Si 2p, Zr 3d, and Al 2p were fitted using a combination of Gaussian-Lorentzian curves with variable proportions, applying least-squares regression. The Ni 2p spectrum was fitted using a combination of GL(80)T(1.5), while Ti 2p was fitted with LA(1.15,1.44,150). 2.4 Catalytic reactions Catalytic activity tests were conducted in a 200 mL stirred-batch autoclave reactor (Parr Model 4590). A mixture containing levulinic acid (0.5 mol L⁻¹, 4.646 g), aniline (0.5 mol L⁻¹, 3.738 g), dioxane (80 mL), and dodecane (internal standard, 7500 mg L⁻¹, 800 µL) was introduced into the reactor along with 100 mg of catalyst. To minimize air exposure, the catalyst was kept under an inert atmosphere before being added to the reactor. After sealing the reactor, it was purged with nitrogen for 10 minutes to completely remove any residual air and then heated to 200°C. Before introducing H₂, an initial liquid sample was taken from the reactor to verify whether any conversion had occurred. The reaction mixture was then pressurized with H₂ up to 50 bar and stirred at 880 rpm for 6 hours. During this period, periodic aliquots were collected and analyzed offline using a GC-FID chromatograph (GC-2030 NEXIS, Shimadzu) equipped with an Elite-1 column (30 m × 0.53 mm). After the reaction, the catalyst was removed from the mixture by filtration. The reaction mixture was then concentrated under reduced pressure using a rotary evaporator. The 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidones were isolated via column chromatography, using silica gel 60 as the stationary phase and a hexane/ethyl acetate (7:3) mixture as the eluting solvent. Finally, the compounds were analyzed by GC-MS. The dispersion, D Ni , is calculated before determining the turnover frequency (TOF, h⁻¹), which is defined by Eq. 2. (2) D Ni = 6 M Ni d p · ρ · σ · N 0 Where MNi is atomic nickel mass (58.693 g·mol−1), ρ is the density of metallic Ni (8.94·10−21 g·nm−3), σ is the cross-sectional area of a Ni atom (0.0649 nm2·at−1), N0 is the Avogadro constant, and dp average particle size (nm) determined by eq-1. The conversion levulinic acid and yield of products are calculated as follow (3) Conversion = n 0 LAc − n LAc n 0 LAc (4) Yield = n p i n 0 LAc Hence, TOF is defined as following (5) r = b ∙ n 0 m cat (6) TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina ( h − 1 ) = r M 2 → 5 M P anilina % Ni ∙ D Ni M Ni ∙ 100 ∙ 60 min 1 h (7) TOF L 1 → 5 M P octylamine ( h − 1 ) = r L 1 → 5 M P octylamine % Ni ∙ D Ni M Ni ∙ 100 ∙ 60 min 1 h (8) TOF acidic sites ( h − 1 ) = r M 1 → M 2 total acidic sites ∙ 60 min 1 h Where b is the slope at initial time, n o is the initial mol of levulinic acid (mmol), m cat is the catalyst mass (gcat) r M 2 → 5 M P anilina is the hydrogenation rate (mol g−1 cat·min−1) from M 2 → 5 M P anilina , r L 1 → 5 M P octylamine is the hydrogenation rate from L 1 → 5 M P octylamine , r M 1 → M 2 is the condensation step from M 1 → M 2 , %Ni is the nickel percentage obtained by ICP and total acidic sites is obtained from pyridine-FTIR measurements. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 1. Adsorption/Desorption isotherm of N2 Table 1 shows the textural properties of NiP catalysts and their supports, for comparison. All catalysts presented a lower surface area than their corresponding supports after the impregnation of NiP. According to Fig. 1, N2 physisorption of NiP catalysts is an IV-type isotherm classical of mesoporous material, according to IUPAC classification [40], whereby NiP/SiO2 and NiP/ZrO2 have a H1, NiP/TiO2 has a H3, and NiP/Al2O3 has a H4 hysteresis loop. Additionally, NiP/SiO2, NiP/ZrO2, and NiP/Al2O3 catalysts have a decrease in the pore volume attributed partially pores blocked. According to Table 1, the molar ratio P/Ni in SiO2 and Al2O3 after reduction was 1.6 and 1.9, respectively. The higher amount of P over the Al2O3 surface presumably blocked the porous then the specific surface area was lower in comparison to SiO2. Regarding NiP/TiO2, which has a slight increment, it is mainly because pristine TiO2 presents macroporous, which are turning into mesoporous since the partial filling of macroporous due to the impregnation of NiP. 2. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) TPR profiles of calcined nickel phosphate precursors (Calcined NiP/MxOy) and calcined nickel precursors (Calcined Ni/MxOy) are depicted in Fig. 2 to see the effect of support in the reduction temperature peaks. Fig. 2 presents for each catalyst a black line, which corresponds to the hydrogen consumption due to the reduction of oxidized Ni supported catalysts, and a red one, to the reduction of oxidized NiP catalysts. Fig. 2a) presents the reduction of oxidized Ni/SiO2 and oxidized NiP/SiO2, where the Ni/SiO2 (black line) shows an on-set temperature at 226°C until 307°C, then there is a clear reduction peak at 381°C and finally a small peak at 479°C. In contrast, NiP/SiO2 (red line) has an on-set temperature at 293°C until 394°C, followed by a broad reduction peak at 780°C. Fig. 2b) represents NiP- and Ni supported on ZrO2, thus Ni/ZrO2 has three important temperatures, the on-set at 233°C and two reduction peaks at 451°C and 532°C, and NiP/ZrO2 presents the on-set at 168°C and offset at 398°C, and a broad reduction peak at 645°C. As to Ni/TiO2 and NiP/TiO2 depicted in Fig. 2c), Ni/TiO2 shows an on-set temperature and one broad reduction peak at 295°C and 513°C, respectively. However, NiP/TiO2 not only has an onset and offset at 282°C and 414°C, respectively, but also a reduction peak at 641°C. Finally, Ni/Al2O3 and NiP/Al2O3 in Fig. 2d) are clearly different from the other catalysts already mentioned. In the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, there is a first reduction peak at 176°C, then there is a slightly constant increase from 261°C up to 801°C, where the nickel has been completely reduced. For NiP/Al2O3, there is an extra peak at 964°C which has been assigned to the reduction of AlPO4 [41]. It is undoubtedly observed that for every NiP catalyst (red line), there is a higher reduction temperature peak with respect to Ni-supported catalysts (black line). The above can be explained because the interaction of nickel-phosphate and supports is stronger than that of Ni-support interaction. It becomes clear that all NiP catalysts, Figs. 2a)-2d), show different reduction peaks due to the interaction of Ni and P with the supports. Regarding the catalysts supported on SiO2, Fig. 2a), the first step between 293°C and 394°C of NiP/SiO2 (red line) matches with the reduction peaks at 226°C-479°C of Ni/SiO2 (black line), indicating that there is a reduction of mostly Ni-O bonding into Ni. Nevertheless, it is expected that other nickel species remain in the oxidized state because of the interaction with Ni-O-P bonding, which is represented by the second reduction peak of Fig. 2a) at 780°C (the red line), due to the fact that the P-O bonding is stronger than that of the Ni-O [42,43]. For NiP/ZrO2 and NiP/TiO2 of Fig. 2b)-c), both catalysts not only present similar behaviour as NiP/SiO2, i.e., a reduction step at lower temperatures, which have a coincidence with the reduction step of Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/TiO2, but also NiP catalysts present a reduction peak at higher temperature, 654°C and 641°C, respectively, assigned to the reduction of Ni-O-P bonding. It must be noted that the second reduction peaks for NiP/ZrO2 and NiP/TiO2 (654°C and 641°C, respectively) are lower than NiP/SiO2 (780°C), thus the interaction of Ni-O-P with TiO2 or ZrO2 is clearly weaker than of Ni-O-P on SiO2. Particularly, in order to discard the consumed hydrogen due to the reduction of TiO2, because it is reducible support and can lead to the creation of oxygen vacancies, a TPR control experiment was carried out over bare TiO2 support, Fig. S1 . The bare TiO2 shows a reduction peak of about 350°C, therefore, the peak at 640°C for NiP/TiO2 in Fig. 2d) is clearly the reduction of Ni-O-P species. Regarding NiP/Al2O3 in Fig. 2d), it is straightforwardly seen that the comparison between Ni (black line) and NiP (red line) shows the beginning is essentially the reduction of nickel, and the main difference is the last reduction peak of AlPO4 near 964°C in NiP/Al2O3 to release phosphorus to form NiP species [41]. The high-temperature signals of TPR can be associated with both phenomena, the reduction reaction between phosphate and nickel to produce NiP and the production of phosphine, PH3, which can react with nickel or be flushed by the gas flow [35]; therefore, there is a loss of phosphorus content that can be seen in the results obtained by ICP-AES in Table 1. The initial molar ratio for all catalysts was P/Ni:2/1. However, the final molar ratios changed after reduction, following the next order NiP/Al2O3 (P/Ni:1.9/1) > NiP/SiO2 (P/Ni:1.6/1) > NiP/TiO2 (P/Ni:1.2/1) > NiP/ZrO2 (P/Ni:0.6/1). The above order can be explained by TPR results; in the case of NiP/SiO2, the main reduction temperature is 780°C, which is higher than 650°C used in the NiP synthesis; therefore, not all the phosphorus was released from the surface. For NiP/ZrO2 catalyst, the reduction temperature of TPR matches the reduction temperature of synthesis, so there is more phosphorus loss from the surface, explaining why the molar ratio is 0.6/1. However, even though the reduction temperature of TPR (640°C) in NiP/TiO2 is similar to the reduction temperature for synthesis (650°C), TiO2 presents SMSI (strong metal support interaction) phenomena, because above 350°C bare TiO2 presents a reduction peak as can be seen in Fig. S1. The reduction of TiO2 not only develops oxygen vacancies but also decorates NiP particles or phosphates on the surface with TiO2-x (0 <x < 1), producing a sort of encapsulation and then protecting phosphate groups and NiP particles. This phenomenon has been well reported, and one of the consequences is that the chemisorption of small molecules, such as H2 or CO, is inhibited on TiO2 surface [44]. Regarding the NiP/Al2O3 catalyst, the strong interaction P-O-Al represented by the reduction peak at 964°C because of AlPO4 species; thus, P releasing is difficult to manage at the temperature used in this work disfavoured the Ni2P formation. It becomes clear that the nature of support can undoubtedly affect the reduction temperature needed to produce NiP particles, since the interaction particle-support could become too strong, implying that there is a higher-temperature shift. It can be concluded that the less strong particle-support interactions are in NiP/ZrO2 and NiP/TiO2 followed by NiP/SiO2 and finally NiP/Al2O3. 3. X-ray diffraction The XRD patterns depicted in Fig. 3 show diffraction patterns of supported NiP, and considering that TPR experiments showed that there are different particle-support interactions, it is expected that there will be different phases depending on the used supports. For NiP/SiO2 (Fig. 3a), it shows six crystallographic planes centered at 2θ= 40.7°, 44.6°, 47.3°, 54.1°, 54.3° and 74.9°, corresponding to Ni2P phase with a hexagonal structure (JCPDS 03–0953) and below 30° there is a broad signal corresponding to amorphous SiO2. As to NiP/ZrO2 in Fig. 3b), the red dotted lines correspond to Monoclinic ZrO2, however, there is a peak at 2θ= 30.1° corresponding to tetragonal structure (not shown in Fig. 3b). According to Rietveld refinement in Fig. S2, there are 88.7 % and 11.3 % of monoclinic and tetragonal phases, respectively. For the NiP/TiO2 catalyst in Fig. 3c), the phases rutile and anatase are presented in 16 % and 84 %, respectively, and no other phases could be assigned. In this regard, NiP phases on either ZrO2 or TiO2 support are not observed because the crystallite sizes could be under the limit detection of equipment. Nevertheless, it has been reported in literature [32,34] that Ni2P on those supports is possible to be synthesized through the temperature-reduction method, and no other NiP phases are presented. For NiP/Al2O3 (Fig. 3d), the possible structures based on NiP are wider, because the particle-support interaction between Ni, P, and Al is too strong, as TPR experiments already suggested (Fig. 2d)). For NiP/Al2O3 catalyst, XRD shows the pattern for NiO and Ni (Fig. 3d), but any nickel phosphide (such as Ni3P, Ni12P5 and Ni2P) patterns are not clearly presented in XRD. Souza et al. [32] reported that Ni12P5 particles over Al2O3 are clearly seen in XRD after 600°C, thus it is not totally discarded the presence of NiP particles on Al2O3 in the catalyst is even when it is not possible to see in XRD. 4. Transmission electronic microscopy (TEM) Fig. 4 displays TEM images and their corresponding histograms of the average particle size distribution for each catalyst. The figure indicates that the average particle size varies among the catalysts, following the trend: NiP/SiO₂ (3.8 nm) > NiP/Al₂O₃ (3.6 nm) > NiP/ZrO₂ (2.6 nm) > NiP/TiO₂ (1.8 nm). Nevertheless, the information obtained from TEM does not allow us to distinguish between metal oxide and metal particles, making it necessary to complement this data with XPS results. Regarding the particle size of NiP/TiO₂, it appears that the SMSI effect encapsulates the particles, preventing their sintering or reduction; therefore, they remain small. Additionally, the particle sizes of NiP on ZrO₂ and TiO₂ explain why it was not possible to observe diffraction patterns for NiP in the XRD analysis shown in Figs. 3c and 3d. Once the particle size is known, dispersion is calculated using Eq. 1, and the results are shown in Table 2. The highest dispersion is observed for NiP/TiO₂, which is expected because the SMSI effect or TiO₂₋ₓ particles have embedded the NiP particles. 5. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The NiP/SiO₂ catalyst in Fig. 5a presents both the oxidized and reduced forms to illustrate the changes between them. On the one hand, the oxidized NiP/SiO₂ exhibits two distinct species in the Ni 2p₃/₂ core spectrum at 855.6 ± 0.1 eV and 857.0 ± 0.1 eV, corresponding to NiO (calypso peak) and Ni(OH)₂ (green peak), respectively [38,45,46]. Additionally, at higher binding energies (BE), three satellite peaks are observed at 859.4 eV, 861.7 eV, and 864.5 eV. On the other hand, the Ni 2p₃/₂ core-level spectrum of the reduced NiP/SiO₂ reveals the presence of a new species at 852.7 ± 0.1 eV, along with two small satellite peaks assigned to Ni⁰/Ni⁺δ, which were fitted according to Grosvenor’s work [47]. It is clear that this new species emerges as a result of the reduction of Ni²⁺ species. Consequently, the NiO and Ni(OH)₂ peaks decrease; however, they are still present in the reduced NiP/SiO₂, and satellite peaks appear at higher binding energies. For NiP/ZrO₂, the oxidized NiP/ZrO₂ in Fig. 5b exhibits species in the Ni 2p₃/₂ core spectrum, assigned to NiO and Ni(OH)₂ at 856.3 eV and 858.3 eV, respectively. Moreover, three satellite peaks are observed at higher binding energies (BE). After the reduction of the NiP/ZrO₂ catalyst, a species at lower BE, corresponding to Ni⁰/Ni⁺δ, appears in the Ni 2p₃/₂ core spectrum at 852.7 ± 0.1 eV, along with two additional satellite peaks at higher BE, as shown in Fig. 5b) (red peaks). Furthermore, almost no oxidized species remain in the catalyst, with Ni⁰/Ni⁺δ being the predominant species on the surface, presumably due to the formation of Ni₂P. In the Ni 2p₃/₂ spectrum for NiP/TiO₂ (Fig. 5c), the oxidized NiP/TiO₂ exhibits NiO and Ni(OH)₂ species along with their corresponding satellite peaks. In contrast, the reduced NiP/TiO₂ not only presents a small peak assigned to Ni⁰/Ni⁺δ at 852.4 ± 0.1 eV, but also shows a slight shift toward lower binding energy for the NiO + Ni(OH)₂ species compared to those in the oxidized NiP/TiO₂, as seen in Fig. 5c). This shift is attributed to the electro-donating TiO₂₋ₓ (Ti³⁺) decorations on the Ni species. To confirm the presence of Ti³ ⁺ in the reduced NiP/TiO₂, the deconvolution of the Ti 2p core-level spectrum was carried out, as depicted in Fig. S3. The results clearly show that the Ti 2p₃/₂ core-level spectrum not only exhibits Ti⁴⁺ species at 458.6 ± 0.1 eV but also includes a contribution from Ti³ ⁺ at 457.2 ± 0.1 eV, confirming the SMSI effect on the NiP/TiO₂ catalyst. Song et al. [48] explained that Ti³ ⁺ ions act as electron donors, transferring electrons through the conduction band from Ti³ ⁺ to Ni species. In this context, the increased electron cloud density over the NiP particles results in a slight shift toward lower binding energies in the NiO and Ni(OH)₂ species of the reduced NiP/TiO₂ [49], compared to the oxidized NiP/TiO₂. Regarding the Ni 2p₃/₂ spectrum for NiP/Al₂O₃, shown in Fig. 5d), the oxidized NiP/Al₂O₃ exhibits the same species as the other oxidized catalysts, NiO + Ni(OH)₂. In contrast, the reduced NiP/Al₂O₃ clearly presents the Ni⁰/Ni⁺δ species at 851.3 eV. To determine the presence of NiP species on the catalysts, XPS core-level spectra for phosphorus were analyzed and are shown in Fig. 6. Regarding the P 2p₃/₂ core-level spectra for NiP/SiO₂ in Fig. 6a, both the oxidized and reduced samples exhibit a contribution from phosphates at 134.8 eV ± 0.1 eV and 134.5 eV ± 0.1 eV, respectively. In the case of reduced NiP/SiO₂, the phosphate contribution is lower than that of oxidized NiP/SiO₂. Moreover, P⁻δ species have been reported to appear at a binding energy of approximately 129 eV [50], however, it is not observed because the Si 2p core-level spectrum for SiO₂ exhibits a broad peak due to plasmon loss energy at ∼125 eV [58], which overlaps with the phosphide species at ∼129 eV. As to the NiP/ZrO2 catalyst, Fig. 6b), the reduced sample clearly shows a new species assigned to P-δ at 129.7 eV, which is lower than the BE of phosphates species (134.2 eV). For NiP/TiO2, Fig. 6c), it was not observed the presence of P-δ because Ti+3 and the effect of SMSI on surface phosphates did not allow NiP/TiO2 to be properly reduced. In the NiP/Al2O3 catalyst, Fig. 6d), the oxidized sample does not show any phosphide contribution, only phosphate species. In contrast, the reduced sample observed a small contribution of P-δ at lower BE with respect to phosphates species, indicating that there was a partial reduction from phosphates to phosphides species. Table 2 summarizes the binding energies (BE) of the Ni 2p₃/₂ core-level spectrum for Ni/Ni⁺δ, NiO, and Ni(OH)₂, as well as the P 2p₃/₂ core-level spectrum for phosphates/phosphides in the reduced samples. Additionally, it includes the surface atomic ratio between Ni/Ni⁺δ and the respective support. For Ni/Ni⁺δ, the binding energy (BE) of the Ni 2p₃/₂ core-level spectrum exhibits a slight shift in the following order: NiP/ZrO₂ (852.9 ± 0.1 eV) > NiP/SiO₂ (852.7 ± 0.1 eV) > NiP/TiO₂ (852.4 ± 0.1 eV) > NiP/Al₂O₃ (851.3 ± 0.1 eV). The shift toward lower BE suggests that nickel has a more metallic nature; in other words, the Ni species in NiP/Al₂O₃ at 851.3 ± 0.1 eV is more likely to be Ni⁰ rather than Ni⁺δ. Conversely, the Ni species in the other catalysts, which exhibit higher BE values, are more likely to be Ni⁺δ than Ni⁰. Regarding the binding energy (BE) of P 2p₃/₂ in Table 2, this information is observed only for two catalysts: NiP/ZrO₂ and NiP/Al₂O₃. In the case of NiP/ZrO₂, the presence of a species at 129.7 ± 0.1 eV suggests the formation of a Ni₂P structure, which is consistent with Moon’s work [35]. In the case of NiP/Al₂O₃, the species at 129.3 ± 0.1 eV in the P 2p₃/₂ spectrum clearly suggests the presence of a nickel phosphide species on Al₂O₃. However, the formation of Ni₂P is unlikely, as the reduction of phosphate groups in NiP/Al₂O₃ requires a high temperature, as observed in the TPR results (Fig. 2d). According to De Souza et al. [32], and the XRD studies at different reduction temperatures for NiP/Al₂O₃ catalysts, the nickel phosphide species on Al₂O₃ is likely Ni₁₂P₅, as the reduction temperature used in this work was 650°C. Therefore, the reduced NiP/Al₂O₃ contains not only Ni⁰ and Ni₁₂P₅ but also NiO and Ni(OH)₂. Regarding the Ni₂P structure over SiO₂, the species at 129 eV is not observed in the P 2p₃/₂ core-level spectrum; however, the XRD pattern for Ni₂P in Fig. 3a confirms its presence in NiP/SiO₂. As for NiP/TiO₂, phosphide species are also not observed, which may be attributed to the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) effect. This effect can hinder the proper reduction of oxidized NiP/TiO₂ by partially suppressing H₂ adsorption. This is evident in the relative abundance of species on TiO₂, where 21 %, 51 %, and 28 % correspond to Ni⁰/Ni⁺δ, NiO, and Ni(OH)₂, respectively. However, the presence of Ni₂P on TiO₂ supports has been previously reported [51]; thus, it is expected that the Ni°/Ni+δ species in TiO2 correspond to Ni2P structure. 6. In-situ adsorption of pyridine in FTIR (Py-FTIR) The nature of the acidic sites on all catalysts was determined by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine, comparing each catalyst at room temperature and 200°C. These results are presented in Fig. 7, with band assignments according to Busca [52]. As can be seen, bands related to Lewis (1455–1438 cm⁻¹) and Brønsted acid sites (1540 cm⁻¹) are present at both temperatures. However, at room temperature, there are also contributions from hydrogen-bonded pyridine, corresponding to very weak acid-base interactions. The catalysts NiP/SiO₂, NiP/ZrO₂, and NiP/TiO₂ (Fig. 7a–c) clearly exhibit different intensities in the Lewis band at both temperatures (RT and 200°C). Furthermore, as the temperature increases from RT to 200°C, the intensity of the Lewis band decreases. However, after heating, the bands remain present. This suggests that the acidic strength of the catalyst is influenced by the interaction between NiP and the supports. Specifically, the acidic strength of NiP/TiO₂ (Fig. 7c) is higher than that of NiP/ZrO₂ (Fig. 7b) and NiP/SiO₂ (Fig. 7a) In contrast, NiP/Al₂O₃ (Fig. 7d) exhibits different bands. In the 1600–1700 cm⁻¹ range at RT, a broad band is assigned to water bands. Additionally, in the 1455–1438 cm⁻¹ range, a band is associated with Lewis acid sites and hydrogen bonding in pyridine. Notably, these bands almost disappear upon heating, suggesting that the acidic sites are not strong enough. This could be attributed to the presence of Ni structures on the Al₂O₃ support in NiP/Al₂O₃, while metallic nickel particles are also present, as indicated by XRD in Fig. 3d. The number of Lewis/Brønsted acidic sites is calculated at 200°C to ensure the removal of weak hydrogen-bonding interactions. Additionally, this temperature is chosen because it corresponds to the reaction conditions used in this study. The results are presented in Table 3. It can be observed that the number of Lewis sites follows the trend: NiP/TiO₂ > NiP/SiO₂ ≈ NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/Al₂O₃. These acidic sites can influence the condensation reaction. [54]. Hence, the condensation reaction in the reductive amination is expected to be favored due to the number of Lewis/Brønsted acidic sites following the aforementioned trend. 3.2 Reaction kinetics of reductive amination of levulinic acid The reaction between aniline and levulinic acid is depicted in Scheme 1, where both reagents interact to form three intermediates, referred to as M1, M2, and M3. The first intermediate, M1, is formed through the condensation reaction between the amine group of aniline and the carboxyl group of levulinic acid, resulting in a linear molecule (M1, m/z = 191). Additionally, the structure of M1 (m/z = 191) was proposed based on the work of Gao et al. [29], due to the presence of nickel in the catalysts. A second condensation reaction occurs intramolecularly between the secondary amine (M2, m/z = 173) and the carbonyl group, leading to the formation of a cyclic molecule. Finally, M2 is in equilibrium with a dehydrogenated molecule (M3, m/z = 171). The proposed reaction pathway is based on measurements obtained from GC-FID and GC-MS, with the corresponding mass spectra shown in Fig. S4.1. 1. Effect of supports on the hydrogenation steps in the synthesis of 5-Methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone Fig. 8 presents the conversion based on levulinic acid (Eq. 3). It is evident that all reactions exhibit conversion at the initial time, as levulinic acid and aniline react immediately through a condensation reaction, as previously explained. Fig. 8 also shows the conversion using NiP/SiO₂, NiP/ZrO₂, NiP/TiO₂, and NiP/Al₂O₃ catalysts. Additionally, Figure S5 presents the conversion of the reaction using Ni/SiO₂ and a system without a catalyst, allowing for a comparison of the catalytic performance of nickel-phosphide catalysts with both references (Ni/SiO₂ and no catalyst). The catalytic systems NiP supported on SiO₂, ZrO₂, and Al₂O₃ exhibit slight changes in conversion over time, despite being under 50 bar of hydrogen. The conversion starts at 50–55 % and gradually increases to approximately 60 % after 360 minutes of reaction (Fig. 8, blue, yellow, and purple lines). Conversely, NiP/TiO₂ shows a significant increase in conversion over time, from approximately 60–80 % (green line). This clearly indicates that NiP/TiO₂ enhances the conversion of levulinic acid and aniline, promoting the formation of intermediate products. In the absence of a catalyst and in the Ni/SiO₂ system, different trends are observed. The system without a catalyst (Figure S5, black line) exhibits only a slight change in levulinic acid conversion. However, the Ni/SiO₂ system (Figure S5, cyan line) shows a continuous increase in conversion, ultimately reaching values higher than those achieved with the NiP/SiO₂, NiP/ZrO₂, and NiP/Al₂O₃ catalysts. To understand the effect of the catalysts on the reductive amination of levulinic acid, the product yields over time (Eq. 4) are shown in Fig. 9 (for NiP/SiO₂, NiP/ZrO₂, NiP/TiO₂, and NiP/Al₂O₃) and in Fig. S6 (for the cases without a catalyst and with Ni/SiO₂). In the absence of a catalyst (Fig. S5), there is a slight formation of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone and γ-valerolactone, reaching approximately 10 % and less than 5 % yield at 360 min, respectively. On the other hand, the use of Ni/SiO₂ (Fig. S6) results in the production of both 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone—via hydrogenation of the intermediate M2—and γ-valerolactone—via hydrogenation and cyclization of levulinic acid. Thus, the increased conversion of levulinic acid observed with Ni/SiO₂ is attributed not only to the production of pyrrolidone but also to the formation of γ-valerolactone. The product yields obtained with the NiP/SiO₂ and NiP/ZrO₂ catalysts are shown in Figs. 9a and 9b. In both cases, the intermediates decrease over time, while 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone increases due to the hydrogenation of intermediate M2. According to Table 2, both NiP/ZrO₂ and NiP/SiO₂ contain Ni₂P species. The presence of phosphorus in the Ni₂P structure withdraws electron density from nickel, as observed in the XPS results for Ni 2p₃/₂ (Figs. 5a and 5b). Consequently, nickel becomes less metallic, which is expected to reduce its hydrogenation capacity. As a benchmark, bare SiO₂ and ZrO₂ supports were tested in the reductive amination reactions. In addition, to evaluate the effect of oxidized nickel phosphide, oxidized NiP/SiO₂ was also tested in order to clarify the contribution of nickel oxide species to the reaction. The results are presented in Figs. S7 and S8. It is evident that the bare supports do not catalyze the hydrogenation of M2, nor do they enhance the rate of the condensation steps. Furthermore, oxidized NiP/SiO₂ does not improve any of the reaction steps involved in the reductive amination, leading to the conclusion that metallic Ni or nickel phosphide species are responsible for the hydrogenation of M2 to 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone. For NiP/TiO₂ (Fig. 9c), this catalyst exhibits the highest levulinic acid (LA) conversion over the reaction time, but a very low yield of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone. In contrast, the intermediates formed indicate that the condensation steps are clearly favored by NiP/TiO₂. LA conversion reaches over 80 % after 120 minutes of reaction, and the intramolecular condensation of M1 to form M2 proceeds rapidly. Nevertheless, the hydrogenation of M2 to produce 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone is significantly hindered. This behavior is attributed to the NiP particles decorated with TiOₓ species (0 < x < 1) as a result of strong metal–support interactions (SMSI), which suppress H₂ adsorption. Thus, the hydrogenation reaction is likely affected by the increased decoration of Ti species on the NiP particles. [55,56]. Moreover, the Ni 2p core-level spectra for NiP/TiO₂ (Fig. 5c) show that the Ni⁰/Niδ⁺ species at 852.5 eV exhibit a low contribution compared to the oxidized Ni²⁺ species. Additionally, the Ti³ ⁺/Ni surface atomic ratio is 6.2. This high ratio suggests that the suppression of hydrogen adsorption and the encapsulation of NiP particles prevent the complete reduction of Ni. Regarding the catalytic performance of NiP/Al₂O₃, depicted in Fig. 9d, the hydrogenation of M2 to 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone proceeds faster than with the other catalysts, due to the presence of Ni species reported in Table 2. Furthermore, to compare all systems, the initial rates for the hydrogenation of M2 to 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone (expressed in mmol g min⁻¹) were calculated based on the initial production rates of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone shown in Fig. 9 (green dotted line). Subsequently, the turnover frequencies ( TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina ) were determined according to Eq. 6, using the particle diameters obtained from TEM analysis (Fig. 4). The results, summarized in Table 4, show that the initial rate of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone production—directly related to the hydrogenation step—follows the trend: NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. This trend is fully consistent with the XPS results, which indicate differences in the formation of Niδ⁺/Ni⁰ species across the various supports. Additionally, the highest TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina is obtained with NiP/Al2O3, because the species is mostly metallic nickel and there is a higher amount of Ni over the support. Therefore, the most active catalyst for the hydrogenation step M2 to 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone was NiP/Al2O3. As to NiP/ZrO2 and NiP/SiO2, it is interesting to note that the TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina number is 1195 h−1 and 429 h−1, respectively. This difference can be explained because Ni2P crystal structure has two different sites, Ni(1) and Ni(2), where Ni(2) has prominently shown higher hydrogenation activity [57]. Therefore, the particles of NiP over ZrO2 clearly present higher hydrogenation activity than NiP/SiO2. Even that NiP/Al2O3 shows a TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina of 1242 h−1, NiP/ZrO2 is slightly lower than that of NiP/Al2O3, having a TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina of 1195 h−1, this could be associated with the structure-dependence of Ni2P in hydrogenation reactions that allows NiP/ZrO2 catalyst to have Ni(2) sites and then hydrogenate an appreciable number of molecules per hour, almost the same as NiP/Al2O3. Finally, the less TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina is performed by NiP/TiO2, where this was explained by SMSI and the suppression of hydrogen adsorption over NiP particles. 2. Effect of support on condensation steps The acidic sites of supports on the catalysts can presumably take a role in condensation steps, this can be seen even in Fig. 8, where the conversion at t = 0 is slightly different in every catalyst. The initial conversions are 61 %, 59, 55 % and 53 % for NiP/TiO2, NiP/ZrO2, NiP/SiO2 and NiP/Al2O3, respectively. It is interesting to note that the support and the number of total acidic sites, Table 3, could influence the initial conversion. Furthermore, the number of total acidic sites follows the next order NiP/TiO2 (100 µmol/g), NiP/ZrO2 (46 µmol/g), NiP/SiO2 (44 µmol/g), and NiP/Al2O3 (22 µmol/g), therefore, the condensation steps could be influenced by these acidic sites. Additionally, the intermediary distribution (M1, M2 and M3) at t = 0 is different as well in every catalyst, implying that the support/acidic sites interaction could influence in the distribution of M1, M2, and M3 products. However, it is not totally clear the contribution of Lewis/Bronsted acidic sites because there is not information about the intensity and the total role of the acidic sites of support and their interaction. Table 4 shows the consumption rate from M1 to M2, which is a condensation step, and it was not possible to find a correlation between acidic sites and the rate, as can be seen in the TOF acidic sites , calculated by eq-8, which follows the next order NiP/SiO2 > NiP/Al2O3 > NiP/ZrO2 > NiP/TiO2. In the case of NiP/TiO2, this catalyst presents the highest number of acidic sites, as can be seen in Table 3, however, the − r M 1 → M 2 is the lowest, 7.41 mmol g−1 min−1 (see Table 4). It presumably seems that not all the acidic sites are catalysing the M1 -> M2 step, and this is expected because NiP/TiO2 catalyst presents the highest levulinic acid conversion, therefore, the acidic sites are catalysing both condensation steps, LAc -> M1 and M1-> M2. On the contrary, NiP/SiO2, NiP/Al2O3, and NiP/ZrO2 show a TOFacidic sites of 516, 313 and 70, respectively, indicating that maybe not all the acidic sites present the same effect on the condensation step from M1 -> M2, where the causes of this phenomenon are not totally understood. 3. Effect of supports on the hydrogenation steps in the synthesis of 5-Methyl-1-octyl-2-pyrrolidone To investigate reductive amination with a different substrate, 1-octylamine was employed to synthesize 5-methyl-1-octyl-2-pyrrolidone, with the reaction pathway depicted in Scheme 2. In this case, no levulinic acid was detected by GC-FID after mixing the reagents; apparently, the conversion was > 95 % (data not shown). However, intermediate molecules L1 and L2 were detected by GC-MS (see Fig. S4.2), and two new peaks were also observed in the GC-FID analysis. The mixture was subjected to hydrogenation conditions, and the results for each NiP catalyst are shown in Fig. 10. L1 and L2 are presumed to be in equilibrium, with L1 being the species hydrogenated to produce 5‑methyl‑1‑octyl‑2‑pyrrolidone. Levulinic acid conversion exceeds 95 % at t = 0, which suggests that acidic sites in the reductive amination of levulinic acid and octylamine do not significantly influence the condensation steps, as the intermediates L1 and L2 only require hydrogenation to form 5‑methyl‑1‑octyl‑2‑pyrrolidone. Regarding the hydrogenation step, the catalysts exhibit the following order in terms of TO F L 1 → 5 M P octylamine as calculated by eq-7 and shown in Table 5: NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂, with NiP/ZrO₂ displaying the highest value. It appears that NiP/ZrO₂ performs better than NiP/Al₂O₃ in the hydrogenation of L 1 → 5 M P octylamine compared to the hydrogenation of M 2 → 5 M P anilina . This behavior can be explained by the formation of Ni₂P as the active species in NiP/ZrO₂ (see Table 2), since Ni₂P exhibits structure sensitivity in hydrogenation reactions. Consequently, the catalysts containing Ni₂P likely hydrogenate L₁ faster than NiP/Al₂O₃, which contains only metallic Ni species on the Al₂O₃ support. In general, the TO F M 2 → 5 M P aniline is higher than that for TO F L 1 → 5 M P octylamine across all catalysts studied, indicating that the pyrrolidone molecule bearing a phenyl substituent (M₂) is hydrogenated more rapidly than the one with an octyl group (L₁). 4. Reactivation of nickel phosphide catalyst The NiP/SiO₂ catalyst was evaluated for its recyclability in the production of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone, as shown in Figure S8. Following the first reaction cycle, the catalyst was reactivated under hydrogen atmosphere and reintroduced into the reactor to replicate the initial operational conditions. As observed in Figure S8, the initial reaction rate for 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone is nearly identical in both cycles. However, after two hours of reaction, the recycled catalyst exhibits a different product distribution, with a lower yield of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone compared to the fresh catalyst. These findings suggest that, although the reactivated NiP/SiO₂ catalyst retains its ability to hydrogenate the intermediate M2 and produce the pyrrolidone molecule, the distribution of products is slightly altered. This indicates potential modifications in the active sites on the catalyst surface after reactivation. Wang et al. [14] reported that the Ni₂P/SiO₂ catalyst remains stable after 6 hours of reaction under continuous reductive amination conditions. Therefore, it is plausible that reactivation at 650°C induced subtle changes in the active sites, which could explain the observed slight variation in product distribution. 4 Conclusions It is evident that the support material plays a crucial role in the formation of NiP species. Depending on the interaction between the particles and the supports, different NiP species can be obtained, or—in the case of TiO₂—the reduction conditions promote the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) effect on the NiP particles. In this study, the catalysts were employed in the reductive amination of levulinic acid with either aniline or octylamine as substituents. For the levulinic acid–aniline system, the catalysts exhibit the following order in the hydrogenation rate of the M₂ intermediate (which leads to the formation of 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone): NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. In the case of Al₂O₃, the presence of metallic Ni (Ni⁰) is responsible for the higher hydrogenation activity toward M₂, followed by Ni₂P species on ZrO₂ and SiO₂, and finally, NiP species on TiO₂, where hydrogen adsorption is suppressed due to SMSI effects. Additionally, acidic sites could influence the condensation steps—specifically, the reaction of levulinic acid with aniline to form M₁ and the subsequent conversion of M₁ to M₂. For instance, the acidic sites on NiP/TiO₂ account for the high rate of condensation in both steps, resulting in high conversion and selectivity toward M₂. However, the influence of acidic sites and their interactions with the supports on the product distribution (M₁, M₂, and M₃) and on the condensation rate ( − r M 1 → M 2 ) remains not fully understood. On the other hand, when levulinic acid was subjected to reductive amination with 1-octylamine, the condensation reaction proceeded with > 95 % conversion, and the primary products detected were the intermediates L₁ and L₂. In this case, the acidic sites may not have played a significant role. However, regarding the hydrogenation of L₁, the catalysts followed the trend: NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. Finally, the effect of the supports on the reductive amination of levulinic acid is critical for understanding how the Ni species on the supports ultimately hydrogenate the intermediates to form the pyrrolidone molecules. Although acidic sites do influence the reaction—especially in the condensation steps—the precise role of the acidic/support interactions remains unclear. coredata.dc:description: The effect of different supports (SiO₂, Al₂O₃, TiO₂, and ZrO₂) on nickel phosphide as an active phase in the reductive amination reaction (using aniline and octylamine) for the synthesis of 5-methyl-N-alkyl-2-pyrrolidone was studied. The experiments were conducted at 200°C and 50 bar H₂, using dioxane as the reactive solvent. Various techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts, including N₂ adsorption–desorption, H₂-temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), pyridine-FTIR, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Firstly, the supports influenced the nickel species present on the surface and the number of acidic sites in each catalyst. Secondly, in the reaction between levulinic acid and aniline, the turnover frequency ( TO F M 2 → 5 M P anilina ) for 5-methyl-1-phenyl-2-pyrrolidone production followed the order: NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. Regarding the reaction between levulinic acid and 1-octylamine, the TO F L 1 → 5 M P octylamine for 5-methyl-N-octyl-2-pyrrolidone production followed the order: NiP/ZrO₂ > NiP/Al₂O₃ > NiP/SiO₂ > NiP/TiO₂. Finally, the supports influenced the type of nickel phosphide species present on the catalyst surface and, consequently, the hydrogenation rate to pyrrolidone molecules.
